properties.title: Gas Leaks Leaks in the Bakken
properties.text1: Methane, along with ethane and other Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), exerts a particularly strong greenhouse effect over the first twenty years of its duration in the atmosphere - an effect some 86 times more powerful than that of CO2. This means that gas leakage from fracking operations has become a crucial driver of rapidly accelerating climate change.
properties.text2:
A recent study used infrared camera imagery to identify leaking well pads and measure their emissions. It was found that a small fraction of individual sites, so-called "superemitters," accounted for a majority of the methane released by the oil and gas industry. Would it be likely to find more such superemitters in a site that has been recklessly developed at high speed over the last decade? Here is a quote from the study's abstract:

"We performed helicopter-based infrared camera surveys of more than 8,000 O&G well pads in seven U.S. basins to assess the prevalence and distribution of high-emitting hydrocarbon sources... The proportion of sites with such high-emitting sources was 4% nationally but ranged from 1% in the Powder River (Wyoming) to 14% in the Bakken (North Dakota)... Over 90% of almost 500 detected sources were from tank vents and hatches" (source here).
